Title: Can the way pigs are handled alter behavioural and physiological measures of affective state?
Authors: Ricard Carreras, Laura Arroyo, Eva Mainau, Daniel Valent, Anna Bassols, Antoni Dalmau, Luigi Faucitano, Xavier Manteca, Antonio Velarde
Supporting quotes for "Age":
- "In this study, 56 female pigs ((Landrace x Large White) x Piétrain) were used."
  - "Treatments started when pigs aged 19 weeks and lasted until 27 weeks of age (slaughter age) (Table 1"
  - "At 9 weeks of age, pigs were transported from a commercial farm to the experimental facilities of IRTA (Monells, Spain) and housed in two rooms of four pens with seven pigs each."
Reasoning for "Age":
The paper states that the pigs used in the study were 9 weeks old when they were transported to the experimental facilities, and the treatments started when the pigs were 19 weeks old and lasted until 27 weeks of age (slaughter age). This indicates that the pigs were juvenile animals, as they were not sexually mature or close to sexual maturity during the experiment.


"At 9 weeks of age, pigs were transported from a commercial farm to the experimental facilities of IRTA (Monells, Spain) and housed in two rooms of four pens with seven pigs each."
"Treatments started when pigs aged 19 weeks and lasted until 27 weeks of age (slaughter age) (Table 1)."
"In this study, 56 female pigs ((Landrace x Large White) x Piétrain) were used."


The paper also mentions that the pigs were female, further confirming that they were juvenile animals.

Title: Does stocking density modify affective state in pigs as assessed by cognitive bias, behavioural and physiological parameters?
Authors: Annalisa Scollo, Flaviana Gottardo, Barbara Contiero, Sandra A Edwards
Supporting quotes for "Age":
- "All experimental procedures and animal care were carried out in accordance with the minimum standards for the protection of pigs laid down by law (Council of The European Union, 2008), and were approved by the Ethical Review Committee of Newcastle University."
  - "A total of 40 entire male and female crossbred pigs (Large White × Landrace), which had previously experienced the same housing and management conditions, were selected at approximately 14 weeks of age and 45 kg live weight."
Reasoning for "Age":
The paper does not explicitly state the age of the pigs used in the experiment. However, it provides some details that suggest the pigs were juvenile:
"A total of 40 entire male and female crossbred pigs (Large White × Landrace), which had previously experienced the same housing and management conditions, were selected at approximately 14 weeks of age and 45 kg live weight."
The paper states that the pigs were selected at approximately 14 weeks of age, which indicates they were not sexually mature or close to sexual maturity. Additionally, the paper mentions the pigs had a live weight of 45 kg, which is typical for juvenile pigs.
"All experimental procedures and animal care were carried out in accordance with the minimum standards for the protection of pigs laid down by law (Council of The European Union, 2008), and were approved by the Ethical Review Committee of Newcastle University."
The fact that the experiment was approved by an ethical review committee also suggests the pigs were juvenile, as experiments on adult pigs may have additional ethical considerations.

Title: Effect of gender and halothane genotype on cognitive bias and its relationship with fear in pigs

Reasoning for "Age":
The paper states that the pigs were transported to the experimental facilities at 9 weeks of age and were tested at 19 weeks of age:
"At 9 weeks of age, pigs were transported from a commercial farm to the experimental facilities of IRTA (Monells, Spain) and housed separately by gender and genotype in 8 pens (6 pigs per pen)."
"At 19 weeks of age, pigs were trained and tested individually for the CB according to the methodology described by Carreras et al. (2015)."
Since the pigs were tested at 19 weeks of age, which is before they would have reached sexual maturity, the age of the animals used in this experiment can be classified as juvenile.

Title: Validation of a novel cognitive bias task based on difference in quantity of reinforcement for assessing environmental enrichment

  - "Bears were housed in pairs in 32-m 2 indoor/outdoor concretefloored enclosures equipped with a hanging tire for enrichment and given daily access to a 0.81-ha semi-natural exercise yard, climbing frame, wooden logs, and water bath, with other socially compatible individuals."
